articles.title: Meet The ‘High-Flying' Goose That Migrates Over The Himalayas. Hint: It's Been Seen Flying Above ...
articles.author: Forbes
articles.summary: A goose can fly over Mount Everest, which is very unusual for a bird of that species. It is one of the few species of birds that can fly at such high altitudes. It's a unique example of upward flight in a bird's repertoire.

articles.title: Call for desilting to prevent monsoon losses
articles.author: Our Correspondent
articles.summary: Pakistan is bracing for a 13% increase in rainfall during the 2025 monsoon season. Monsoon-induced flooding has historically inflicted severe economic damage across South Asia. The 2020 floods in the region caused an estimated $105 billion in damages, with Pakistan accounting for $1.5 billion of that total. In 2024, Nepal experienced floods resulting in over Rs17 billion in losses. In Islamabad, sectors such as G-10, F-10 and I-10 face chronic drainage issues.

articles.title: Iran-Israel missile attacks risk wider region conflict
articles.summary: Australia is concerned that the tit-for-tat bombing campaigns by Iran and Israel could spill into a wider conflict in the Middle East and Australia is very concerned about the consequences.       .   in Israel and Iran are bombing each other.

articles.title: Pace and scale of Canadian wildfires could reshape the landscape, experts say
articles.author: Mellen
articles.summary: The 2025 wildfire season is on track to be the second-largest on record. Canada will host the Group of Seven Summit on Monday in Calgary, Alberta. It will not feature a specific session on climate change. Indigenous people are most affected by the blazes in Canada and have the least input in managing and preventing them.

articles.title: Experts urge timely desilting of drains to prevent monsoon losses
articles.author: Sajid Salamat
articles.summary: Pakistan is bracing for a 13% increase in rainfall during the 2025 monsoon season. Monsoon-induced flooding has historically inflicted severe economic damage across South Asia. The 2020 floods in the region caused an estimated $105 billion in damages, with Pakistan accounting for $1.5 billion of that total. In 2024, Nepal experienced floods resulting in over Rs17 billion in losses. In Islamabad, sectors such as G-10, F-10 and I-10 face chronic drainage issues. In informal settlements, many homes are built along drainage canals.

articles.title: Health advisory against swimming at 3 Long Island beaches over concerns of elevated bacteria levels
articles.author: Eyewitness News
articles.summary: Hewlett Point Beach in East Rockaway, Island Park Beach in Island Park and Philip Healey Beach in Massapequa are advised against swimming. Biltmore Beach Club is closed until further notice due to elevated bacterial levels. The advisory will be lifted at 6 a.m. on Monday unless there is additional heavy rainfall or water samples reveal elevated bacteria levels.

articles.title: Wayanad records high rainfall between June 2024 and May 2025, says Hume Centre
articles.author: The Hindu Bureau
articles.summary: After four years of below-average rainfall, Wayanad has recorded significantly high rainfall between June 2024 and May 2025. The rainfall monitoring data shows that Lakkidi recorded the highest rainfall in the district, with a staggering 7,611 mm over the 12-month period. Mattillayam (7,022 mm) and Niravilpuzha (6,463 mm) also reported exceptionally high totals. The southeastern regions recorded the lowest rainfall.

articles.title: Nearly half of Fresno residents will flee due to climate risks, report predicts
articles.author: Thaddeus Miller
articles.summary: Risk-assessing firm First Street predicts 45.8% of Fresno County residents would leave the county by 2055 because of rising insurance rates and decreasing land values. The report also projected a nearly 15% impact on costs in the region as home values decrease and the cost to insure them rise.

articles.title: Researchers Confirm Arctic Permafrost Is Releasing Methane
articles.author: Nelleke van Niekerk
articles.summary: Arctic permafrost is thawing and releasing methane into the atmosphere. Methane is a greenhouse gas far more potent than carbon dioxide. This discovery is a wake-up call wrapped in the chilling winds of the North. It matters more than ever if you love weather, wild landscapes or simply want to understand how our world is changing.

articles.title: Ukraine war pumps 180M tons of CO2 into atmosphere, causing $33B in damage
articles.author: Vasylyna Kopytko
articles.summary: The war in Ukraine is speeding up climate change. The Ministry of Environmental Protection assessed the direct and indirect greenhouse gas emissions caused by military actions in Ukraine. Russia caused $33 billion in environmental damage over 24 months of war. Global warming could open new opportunities for Ukraine's agriculture.

articles.title: Reproductive Health Archives
articles.author: James Carter
articles.summary: Global fertility rates are in freefall. The implications for everything from economies to social structures are profound. Read more at: The Baby Bust.    iReport: Why Global Fertility Rates are Plummeting and What it Means for You.  IReport:

articles.title: Gulls and their guano are a filthy menace
articles.author: Guardian Staff
articles.summary: The decline in gull numbers is a cause for concern, but it's humans who are the problem. Urban gulls excrete a lot of guano, which is corrosive, damaging and polluting. Some towns avoid this by trying to prevent gull-feeding, while others try to restore gull habitats.

articles.title: NZ's carbon forestry offsets on trial in High Court case
articles.author: Marc Daalder
articles.summary: Lawyers for Climate Action has filed a world-first legal challenge in Wellington. They argue the current government has erred in how it revised its predecessor's climate plan and how it assembled its own. They also argue that scientific research suggests carbon sequestered by trees should not offset carbon emitted to the atmosphere.

articles.title: Floods claim 19 lives in Kinshasa, DR Congo
articles.author: Rishav Kothari
articles.summary: At least 17 people were killed by floods and landslides in Kinshasa's western neighborhood of Ngaliema due to heavy rains from Friday through Saturday. Two avenues in the city were also cut off due to the flooding. The area is vulnerable to flooding due to its largely unplanned infrastructure and the equatorial climate.

articles.title: Dakshina Kannada Issues Red Alert as Heavy Rainfall Intensifies, Emergency Protocols Activated
articles.author: Mangalorean News Desk
articles.summary: Dakshina Kannada has been placed under a red alert by the IMD and the Karnataka State Natural Disaster Monitoring Center. A district-wide closure has been mandated for all Anganwadi centers, primary and secondary schools, and both government-aided and private educational institutions within the Mangalore, Bantwal, Ullal, Moodbidri, and Mulki taluks. Incident Commanders are required to maintain heightened vigilance, respond to public grievances, and maintain continuous communication with the District Collector's Control Room. Fishermen are advised not to venture out to sea until further notice.

articles.title: Could climate change drive Ukrainians to relocate? Ukrainian climatologist weighs in
articles.author: Vasylyna Kopytko
articles.summary: Vira Balabukh is a climatologist at the Ukrainian Hydrometeorological Institute and the National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine. She believes Ukrainians will not become climate refugees due to climate change, because they live in temperate latitudes and are far from the ocean. However, some Ukrainians from certain regions may consider relocating. Global warming could open new opportunities for Ukraine's agriculture.

articles.title: More than 50 villages in southern Laos flooded as forecasters warn of more rain
articles.author: The Star
articles.summary: Residents in 54 villages in Khongxedon district, Saravan province, are suffering from flash floods after heavy rain in recent days, unleashed by tropical storm Wutip. The district has been flooded since June 13, affecting farmland, houses, schools and animals. There have been no reports of injuries or deaths. Authorities are moving residents, vehicles and animals to safe places, and monitoring the flood situation.

articles.title: Canada's Conners withdraws from US Open due to injury
articles.author: Afp Afp
articles.summary: Griffin, GA (30223) is experiencing mixed clouds and sun today. A stray shower or thunderstorm is possible. High 87F. Winds WSW at 5 to 10 mph. Tomorrow will be partly cloudy, with a few showers or thunderstorms.

articles.title: Residents of elite island living in fear as sea levels predicted to rise by a FOOT in next 30 years
articles.author: Samantha Rutt
articles.summary: According to NOAA's projections, sea levels around Nantucket are expected to rise by more than a foot by 2055. High tide flooding events have increased from six per year in the 1960s to an average of 37 times in 2020 and a record-setting 75 times in 2023. Town adopted a Coastal Resilience Plan in 2021, which identified four major concerns - groundwater table rise, coastal flooding, high tide flooding and coastal erosion. The plan has identified over 40 proposed projects over the next 15 years at a hefty cost of $930 million.

articles.title: High migration pressures housing market
articles.author: Leith van Onselen
articles.summary: There were 1,119,910 permanent and long-term arrivals in the year to April, offset by 679,580 departures. Both numbers are close to a record high. There were 440,330 net arrivals, down from a peak of 498,270 in February 2024.

articles.title: Coastal Karnataka records normal rainfall in June, says KSNDMC
articles.author: The Hindu Bureau
articles.summary: Coastal Karnataka recorded 232 mm of rainfall against the normal 280 mm from June 1 to June 13. Highest rainfall in Karnataka was 189.5 mm at Pudu gram panchayat, under Mangaluru taluk in Dakshina Kannada. Widespread rains were observed in five districts. IMD said heavy to very heavy rain with sustained winds is likely to occur at one or two places on Monday and Tuesday.

articles.title: June and July May Mean Flightless Geese In Your Area
articles.author: All On Georgia
articles.summary: After molting season, geese can be difficult to control as they are unable to fly. There are several ways to deter geese from using your property. Canada geese are a protected species under state and federal law. It is illegal to hunt, kill, sell, purchase or possess them except in Georgia's migratory bird regulations.

articles.title: Emperor penguins show dramatic decline in a region of Antarctica, satellite photos show
articles.author: Christina Larson
articles.summary: The population of emperor penguins in one part of Antarctica appears to be declining faster than previously thought. The estimated population of 16 penguin colonies declined 22% between 2009 and 2024. Climate change is shrinking the amount of available sea ice. King penguins are making a surprising comeback in Patagonia.

articles.title: Emperor penguins show dramatic decline in a region of Antarctica, satellite photos show
articles.author: Christina Larson
articles.summary: The population of emperor penguins in one part of Antarctica is declining faster than previously thought, according to a new analysis of satellite imagery. Climate change is shrinking the amount of available sea ice, which is important for penguins because they breed on sea ice and forage on it. More predators like leopard seals and orcas may be able to come closer to the colonies if sea ice breaks up earlier in the year.

articles.title: Climate change cited in Iceland, Greenland heat wave
articles.author: NWA Online
articles.summary: Human-caused climate change boosted Iceland and Greenland's temperatures by several degrees during the last few years.      Â   in Iceland and in Greenland.  in Greenland's temperature rose by a few degrees during that period due to climate change.

articles.title: Five killed and another two people missing in Vietnam typhoon floods
articles.summary: Typhoon Wutip made landfall in southern China on Saturday. It was downgraded to a tropical storm after swooping up the Gulf of Tonkin on Vietnam's flank. More than 70,000 hectares (172,000 acres) of cropland were flooded in Vietnam.

articles.title: Death toll rises to five, two missing as Typhoon Wutip floods submerge farmland in Vietnam
articles.summary: Typhoon Wutip made landfall in southern China yesterday with winds gusting up to 128 km/h. It was downgraded to a tropical storm after swooping up the Gulf of Tonkin on Vietnam's flank. More than 70,000 hectares of cropland were flooded by the deluge.

articles.title: We Cannot Afford To Treat Climate Disasters As Surprises
articles.author: Soko Directory Team
articles.summary: Kenya has one of the most developed climate monitoring systems in the region. The Kenya Livestock Insurance Program provides drought coverage for vulnerable pastoralists in arid and semi-arid counties. Kenya is working with global partners to develop a framework for disaster risk financing. Mobile-based insurance platforms are ideal for increasing farmers' access to insurance.

articles.title: Australia Indirectly Funds Russia Through Fuel Imports, Analysis Reveals
articles.author: The Epoch Times
articles.summary: Australia has spent $1.5 billion (US$953 million) in support to Ukraine, but it has inadvertently channelled even more money to Russia via indirect fuel imports. Centre for Research on Energy and Clean calls it a significant failing of Western sanctions.

articles.title: Global Warming vs. Climate Change: Know what is the real difference, causes and steps for controlling
articles.author: TOI Science Desk
articles.summary: The terms 'global warming' and 'climate change' are used interchangeably. Global warming is the long term increase in the average temperature of the Earth caused by human activities like burning fossil fuels, deforestation, increase in transportation and so on. Climate change is caused by the increase of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. The factors that are contributing in the rise of Earth's temperature in the form of global warming are: Deforestation, greenhouse gas emissions, burning of fossil fuels and transportation.

articles.title: Letters to the editor, June 15: ‘U.S. Ambassador Pete Hoekstra claims America is a welcoming place. Really?'
articles.author: The Globe
articles.summary: Re 'Massive fires across Alberta have helped put climate change back on the G7 agenda' (June 12): Trump administration officials employ phrases such as 'secular, woke religion' to describe climate change. Re 'Bus-only lanes can irritate drivers, but they help city dwellers share limited space' (Opinion, June 7): Please take blame away from the poor Uber drivers and delivery people.

articles.title: Climate change impact, a looming national crisis
articles.author: emmakd
articles.summary: There is a group of people looking for a place to hang out. They are looking for the place where there is a place where they can see the people who are interested in this place. There is also a group looking for places where there are people who want to hang around.

articles.title: Australia urges Israel, Iran to exercise restraint
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: Australia's foreign minister urged Israel and Iran to "not escalate" a "perilous" situation that could affect the wider Middle East. Penny Wong told ABC News that she spoke with Iran and Israel on Sunday and urged them not to escalate the situation.

articles.title: Five killed, two missing in Vietnam floods
articles.author: gulftoday
articles.summary: Typhoon Wutip made landfall in southern China on Saturday with winds of up to 128 km/h. Five people were killed in central Vietnam and two more are missing. More than 70,000 hectares of cropland were flooded. Natural disasters are becoming more severe and frequent in Vietnam due to climate change.

articles.title: orbit Archives
articles.author: Alexandra Hartman
articles.summary: Solar Activity Blamed for Escalating Satellite Failures: A New Nasa Study. Rising solar activity is significantly contributing to the increased Fallout of Satellites Orbiting Earth. This has profound implications for our reliance on space-based technology. The Sun's Unpredictable Activity is Unfredictable.

articles.title: WA government steadfast on prescribed burns despite 'mass' tree felling
articles.summary: Hundreds of tingle trees were felled in a prescribed burn in Western Australia last December. There are fresh calls for a review of prescribed burning in the state. The fire is estimated to have destroyed about 1,000 trees at that time. The cause of the burn is unknown.

articles.title: Dengue And The Climate Crisis: A Call For Multi-Sectoral Response
articles.author: Shivani Singh
articles.summary: There has been a rise in the number of dengue cases across Kerala and Karnataka due to climate change. India is estimated to bear one-third of the global d Dengue caseload. The EquiHealth Alliance convened a high-level World Environment Day summit on 5th June 2025 titled "Let's Come Together to Defeat Dengue" in order to address the problem.

articles.title: Dutch scientists warn of harsh winters, sea ice if Atlantic current collapses
articles.summary: The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) is a critical component of global ocean circulation that includes the Gulf Stream. AMOC transports warm water from the tropics to the North Atlantic, keeping Western Europe's climate relatively mild. Recent data suggests the AMOC is weakening, although scientists disagree on how far the trend has progressed.

articles.title: Five killed, two missing as floods ravage Vietnam
articles.author: Agency Report
articles.summary: Typhoon Wutip made landfall in southern China on Saturday with winds of up to 128 km/h (80 mph). It was downgraded to a tropical storm after swooping up the Gulf of Tonkin on Vietnam's flank. More than 70,000 hectares (172,000 acres) of cropland were flooded.

articles.title: Nottinghamshire Wildlife Trust writes of the decline of insect populations, and the impact on wildlife
articles.summary: Insect numbers have declined by 60% in the last five years. Erin McDaid of Nottinghamshire Wildlife Trust is concerned about the rate and scale of the decline in flying insect numbers. Insects play a vital role in pollinating food crops and sustaining many creatures, including birds like the robin. Human activities such as habitat destruction, pesticides use and air and water pollution may be to blame for the decline.

articles.title: Winter is flaring up eczema for about a third of Aussies who suffer from the irritating skin condition
articles.summary: Winter is flaring up eczema for about a third of Aussies who suffer from the irritating skin condition, according to the Skin Foundation of Australia (SFA).       .   ezema is a skin condition caused by the weather.

articles.title: Condition that only gets worse in winter
articles.summary: Eczema is a dry, itchy and inflammatory skin disease that usually begins in childhood and affects one in five children and one in 10 adults. Dermatologist Deshan Sebaratnam says people are more prone to eczema during winter because of dry air, heaters and long showers. He recommends using thick and greasy moisturisers that contain glycerine and ceramides to trap water in the skin and avoiding products with fragrances, perfumes or food.

articles.title: Winter is flaring up eczema for about a third of Aussies who suffer from the irritating skin condition
articles.author: Emma Kirk
articles.summary: Eczema is a dry, itchy and inflammatory skin disease that usually begins in childhood and affects one in five children and one in 10 adults. It is caused by dry air, heaters, woollen jumpers and long, hot showers. Dermatologist Deshan Sebaratnam says people with eczema should see their GP or dermatologist.

articles.title: Intense rainfall days rising in city, so is rain volume during such events, finds 10-yr study
articles.author: Richa Pinto
articles.summary: There has been an increase in the number of 100mm+ rainfall days annually in Mumbai in the last three years. The average volume of high-intensity rainfall in last six years climbed to 182mm, a sharp increase from the 131mm average recorded in the previous five years. Rising temperatures of Arabian Sea are causing a rise in moisture during peak monsoon days.

articles.title: PHOTOS: 'No Kings' protest draws thousands to Pennsylvania's capital city
articles.author: Christina Lengyel
articles.summary: Griffin, GA (30223) is experiencing a mix of clouds and sun today. A stray shower or thunderstorm is possible. High 87F. Winds WSW at 5 to 10 mph. Tomorrow will be partly to mostly cloudy, with a few showers or thunderstorms.

articles.title: An 'Absolutely Alarming' Find on Emperor Penguins
articles.author: Newser Editors
articles.summary: The population of emperor penguins in one part of Antarctica appears to be declining faster than previously thought, according to a new analysis of satellite imagery released Tuesday. The estimated population of 16 penguin colonies has declined 22% between 2009 and 2024, mainly due to climate change. The colonies studied represent about 30% of the total emperor penguin population.

articles.title: ‘We know Iran is a threat': Australia backs Israel's ‘right to self-defence' but won't play ...
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Penny Wong says situation in Middle East is very perilous. Anthony Albanese urges Australians to leave the region as he calls for their citizens to do so.   Â   in a statement by Penny Wong and Anthony Albaniaese.  in the statement by Albanese and Penny Wong.

articles.title: Climate change leads to spread of infection-causing fungi, scientists say
articles.author: Yahoo Daily News
articles.summary: There will be an increased risk of infection due to harmful fungi due to climate change, according to scientists. There will be millions more people at risk from an infection-causing fungi, which is likely spreading due to warming global temperatures, scientists say.

articles.title: Global Warming vs. Climate Change: Know what is the real difference, causes and steps for controlling
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: The terms 'global warming' and 'climate change' are often used by people interchangeably. The environment is getting brutally affected by both of these issues and also, there are multiple issues that can be seen today in the world's environment.    .

articles.title: Climate change impact, a looming national crisis
articles.author: Ghana Business News
articles.summary: The impacts of climate change are well felt in Ghana. Rising temperatures and unpredictable rainfall patterns alter the rhythms of farming. It is threatening the socio-economic livelihoods of people who depend on farming activities for their upkeep and survival. Taking proactive measures can reduce the vulnerability of Ghana's agricultural sector and protect farmers' livelihoods.

articles.title: Antarctica's remote wildlife sanctuaries disturbed by human noise, study says
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: The noise of small motors and humming generators is reaching some of the continent's most fragile refuges. A single power unit over a mile away can pierce the atmosphere. Animals respond to noise exposure by altering their usual behavior and reduced efficiency in foraging or responding to predators.

articles.title: Government Undermines Regional Powers To Protect Coastal Biodiversity
articles.author: Scoop
articles.summary: 'This is a direct attack on the ability of local communities to safeguard their coastal environments,' said EDS Chief Operating Officer Shay Schlaepfer. EDS is a company that provides services to coastal communities. It is a subsidiary of EDS.

articles.title: Meet The ‘High-Flying' Goose That Migrates Over The Himalayas. Hint: It's Been Seen Flying Above The 5th Highest Mountain On Earth
articles.author: Scott Travers
articles.summary: There are over 10,000 bird species in the world. Most choose to fly at relatively low altitudes. Ruppell's griffon is the world's highest-flying bird. The bar-headed goose is one of the only birds on Earth capable of crossing the Himalayas on an annual basis. The entire migration of the geese spans around 80 days and takes them over a thousand miles.

articles.title: Why nuclear war, not the climate crisis, is humanity's biggest threat, according to one author
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Mark Lynas has spent decades pushing for action on climate change. Now he says nuclear war is even greater threat than climate change, because of nuclear war, he says. He is worried about it more than global warming, because it is a weapon of mass destruction.

articles.title: 'Very few flood maps' account for the risk of climate change, expert warns
articles.author: system
articles.summary: The latest advice to engineers and policy makers warns that storms will increase in intensity and frequency depending on how quickly the world warms, according to the latest advice from the IPCC.    .      "Storm frequency and intensity will increase depending on the amount of global warming"

articles.title: Five killed in Vietnam typhoon floods
articles.author: Agence France-Presse . Hanoi
articles.summary: Typhoon Wutip made landfall in southern China on Saturday with winds of up to 128 km/h. It was downgraded to a tropical storm after swooping up the Gulf of Tonkin on Vietnam's flank. More than 70,000 hectares of cropland were flooded.
